{{stub}}
{{Exclusive|java}}

'''Timelines''' control game behavior and visuals based on the absolute day time through [[environment attribute]]s.

== JSON format ==

<div class="treeview" style="margin-block-end: 1em;">
* {{nbt|compound}}: The root element of the timeline.
** {{nbt|integer|period_ticks}}: Optional. Defines the duration in ticks over which the timeline will repeat. If omitted, the timeline will not repeat.
** {{nbt|compound|tracks}}: A map between namespaced [[environment attribute]] IDs and a corresponding attribute track object.
*** {{nbt|compound|}}: An attribute track.
**** {{nbt|string}}{{nbt|compound|ease}}: The easing type used to ease the interpolation between keyframes (see below). Default is {{code|linear}}. Note that easing only has an effect for attributes which support interpolation.
***** {{nbt|string}}: One of the simple easing types shown below.
***** {{nbt|compound}}: A cubic Bézier curve.
****** {{nbt|list|cubic_bezier}}: A list of 4 {{nbt|double}} doubles providing the coordinates of the 2 control points in the order x1, y1, x2, y2.
**** {{nbt|string|modifier}}: The ID of an [[Environment attribute#Modifiers|environment attribute modifier]]. The default is {{code|override}}.
**** {{nbt|list|keyframes}}: A list of keyframes for the track.
***** {{nbt|compound}}: A keyframe.
****** {{nbt|integer|ticks}}: A value between 0 and {{code|period_ticks}} (if specified) which defines the tick within the period at which the keyframe's value will be active.
****** {{nbt|compound|value}}: The value for the attribute modifier.
</div>

=== Easing types ===

{{wip|section=1|Adding graphs for each of the easing types would be helpful.}}

An easing type specifies the interpolation easing between keyframes of an attribute track.

Two easing types are available which do not interpolate into or out from keyframes:

{| class="wikitable"
|-
! Easing type
! Behavior
|-
| {{code|constant}}
| Always selects the value from the previous keyframe.
|-
| {{code|linear}}
| Linearly interpolates between the previous and next keyframes, also known as {{w|linear interpolation|lerp}}.
|}

The rest of the easing types are all variations of a set of interpolation kinds, resized and moved to fit each segment of the track. Each is available in three forms; {{code|in_}}, {{code|out_}}, and {{code|in_out_}}. {{code|in_}} applies the easing ''from'' the value of a keyframe after it's been passed, {{code|out_}} applies the easing ''into'' the value of a keyframe before it's been passed, and {{code|in_out_}} combines the two and applies the easing both ''from'' a keyframe and ''into'' the next one.

The types of easing which support {{code|in_}}, {{code|out_}}, and {{code|in_out_}} are as follows:

{| class="wikitable"
|-
! Interpolation kind
!Ease in
!Ease out
!Ease in and out
!Easing behavior
!Ease-out formula
|-
| {{code|back}}
|{{code|in_back}}
|{{code|out_back}}
|{{code|in_out_back}}
|Pulls back beyond the target value before easing into it.
|<math>y = 1 + 2.70158 (x - 1)^3 + 1.70158(x - 1)^2</math>
|-
| {{code|bounce}}
|{{code|in_bounce}}
|{{code|out_bounce}}
|{{code|in_out_bounce}}
|Bounces against the target value 3 times before stopping.
|<math>f(x) = \begin{cases}
    7.5625 x^2, & \text{if }0 \le x < \frac4{11} \\
    7.5625 \left(x - \frac6{11}\right)^2 + \frac34, & \text{if }\frac4{11} \le x < \frac8{11} \\
    7.5625 \left(x - \frac9{11}\right)^2 + \frac{15}{16}, & \text{if }\frac8{11} \le x < \frac{10}{11} \\
    7.5625 \left(x - \frac{21}{22}\right)^2 + \frac{63}{64}, & \text{if }\frac{10}{11} \le x \le 1
\end{cases}</math>
|-
| {{code|circ}}
|{{code|in_circ}}
|{{code|out_circ}}
|{{code|in_out_circ}}
|Uses a circular curve to ease into the target value.
|<math>y = \sqrt{1 - (x - 1)^2}</math>
|-
| {{code|elastic}}
|{{code|in_elastic}}
|{{code|out_elastic}}
|{{code|in_out_elastic}}
|Wobbles around the target value 4 times.
|<math>y = 2^{-10 x} \sin\left(\frac{2 \pi}3 (10 x - 0.75) \right) + 1</math>
|-
| {{code|sine}}
|{{code|in_sine}}
|{{code|out_sine}}
|{{code|in_out_sine}}
|Eases into the target value with a sinusoidal curve.
|<math>y = \sin\left(\frac{\pi x}2\right)</math>
|-
| {{code|quad}}
|{{code|in_quad}}
|{{code|out_quad}}
|{{code|in_out_quad}}
|A quadratic curve with its origin at the target value.
|<math>y = 1 - (1 - x)^2</math>
|-
| {{code|cubic}}
|{{code|in_cubic}}
|{{code|out_cubic}}
|{{code|in_out_cubic}}
|A cubic curve with its origin at the target value.
|<math>y = 1 - (1 - x)^3</math>
|-
| {{code|quart}}
|{{code|in_quart}}
|{{code|out_quart}}
|{{code|in_out_quart}}
|A quartic curve with its origin at the target value.
|<math>y = 1 - (1 - x)^4</math>
|-
| {{code|quint}}
|{{code|in_quint}}
|{{code|out_quint}}
|{{code|in_out_quint}}
|A quintic curve with its origin at the target value.
|<math>y = 1 - (1 - x)^5</math>
|-
| {{code|expo}}
|{{code|in_expo}}
|{{code|out_expo}}
|{{code|in_out_expo}}
|An exponential curve with its origin at the starting value.
|<math>y = 1 - 2^{-10 x}</math>
|}
